sect1.simpara: When programming PHP-Gtk applications and surfing through the manual, you will find some rather cryptic acronyms. Here is the explanation for the most important ones.

sect2.title: PHP
sect2.simpara: PHP is a widely-used general-purpose scripting language that is especially suited for Web development and can be embedded into HTML.

sect2.title: GTK
sect2.simpara: GTK+ is a library for creating graphical user interfaces. It works on many UNIX-like platforms, Windows, and on framebuffer devices.
The GTK+ library itself contains widgets, that is, GUI components such as GtkButton or GtkTextView.
It depends on the other libraries like GDK, Pango, Atk and GLib.

sect2.title: GDK
sect2.simpara: GDK is the abstraction layer that allows GTK+ to support multiple windowing systems. GDK provides drawing and window system facilities on X11, Windows, and the Linux framebuffer device.

sect2.title: Pango
sect2.simpara: Pango is a library for internationalized text handling. It centers around the PangoLayout object, representing a paragraph of text. Pango provides the engine for GtkTextView, GtkLabel, GtkEntry, and other widgets that display text.

sect2.title: Atk
sect2.simpara: ATK is the Accessibility Toolkit. It provides a set of generic interfaces allowing accessibility technologies to interact with a graphical user interface.
For example, a screen reader uses ATK to discover the text in an interface and read it to blind users. GTK+ widgets have built-in support for accessibility using the ATK framework.
